1528712915_1AHEQxyRG9s6owyJHShB4U4rg9GL5.body:
> [gamer](#comment_1_15vucp19CsYjbEqN1gbkC3TwyAHSTp98hh): I agree.  Mobile devices are rather popular ;) Torrents on such devices are not a good idea.  There should be a solution that allows users on mobile to use the system without eating up all of their data. [...]

I have an unlimited data plan. I'll torrent all month if I want to. All that I lose is prioritization after 22GB. The bigger issue is scheduling and bandwidth throttling ZeroNet to not interfere with other apps using bandwidth.

> [gamer](#comment_4_15vucp19CsYjbEqN1gbkC3TwyAHSTp98hh): Bandwidth on mobile devices is generally more expensive than bandwidth at home, work, or on a dedicated server. [...]

Apparently ZeroNet doesn't seed bigfiles when the page isn't open, so is battery really an issue?

Anyway, if you're not on an unlimited data plan, then that's a bigger issue on the users' own behalf than with ZeroNet.

Not that I object to a data cap, but IMO it can be a last priority. Bandwidth throttling is more important and I think it can be as easy as setting what percent of time downloading and uploading take place, like a PWM fan, translating to what percent of bandwidth downloading and uploading take up.
Another thing to add here is that these features can be obtained via rootless firewalls, but you sacrifice Tor availability, so I see the necessity in native support.
